title: I would just like to point out how incredibly well Kindred was designed
body:
http://vignette1.wikia.nocookie.net/leagueoflegends/images/a/a2/Kindred_The_Wolf_1.png/revision/latest?cb=20150915211231
Seriously, I've got to say, Kindred is one of the best designed champion in League of Legends. From the voiceover to the overall gameplay, I always get the chills when anything involving Kindred's story is mentioned.

I was reading through Kindred's voiceover (looking for some stuff on how Kindred could be Jhin - it's a theory, look it up!), and I've got to say, Kindred has some incredibly chilling quotes.

#Upon buying {{item:3026}} Guardian Angel
- Wolf: *"For us, or them?*

---

#During the Death Screen

 - Lamb: *"What do all stories have in common, dear Wolf?"*
  - Wolf: *"They end."*

 ---

 - Wolf: *"Lamb, tell me a story."*
  - Lamb: *"There was once a pale man with dark hair who was very lonely."*
    - Wolf: *"Why was it lonely?"*
      - Lamb: *"All things must meet this man, so they shunned him."*
        - Wolf: *"Did he chase them all?"*
          - Lamb: *"He took an axe and split himself in two right down the middle."*
            - Wolf: *"So he would always have a friend?"*
              - Lamb: *"So he would always have a friend."*

---

#Movement
 - Lamb: *"Those who run from death... stood still in life."*

---

 - Wolf: *"And everywhere Lamb went..."*
  - Lamb: *"... Wolf was sure to follow."*

---

 - Lamb: *"And everywhere Lamb went..."*
  - Wolf: *"Wolf was sure to follow!"*

---

#Taunting an enemy {{champion:6}} Urgot

 - Lamb: *"Sometimes, death is a blessing."*

---

#Upon marking an enemy

 - Lamb: *"Treasure your final moments."*

 - Lamb: *"Eternal twilight calls for you."*

 - Lamb: *"A fine life reaches its conclusion."*

 - Lamb: *"Our mark looms over you."*

---

#Upon killing a hunted enemy

 - Lamb: *"All your life has led to this moment."*

 - Lamb: *"All life is temporary."*

 - Lamb: *"All things, great and small..."*
Wolf: *"... **die**."*

---

#Upon casting Lamb's Respite

 - Lamb: *"Shine once more, before the end."*

 - Lamb: *"Savour life's closing act."*

 - Lamb: *"Not here, not yet."*

---

One of the coolest things about Kindred is the fact that they are so incredibly well-represented as Life & Death, Yin & Yang. Lamb is white, Wolf is black; Lamb is somber, Wolf is playful; Lamb has a soft voice, Wolf has a rugged voice.
It's beautiful, really, and unlike Lamb's quote, *"Beauty fades. That is why it is beautiful"*, the incredible design behind Kindred will never fade.

replies.body: I felt the gameplay left a lot to be desired.  Wolf feels more like a pet than something comprising a dual entity.

Let's also not forget what the entirety of that champion is, basically a grim reaper.

How does that translate to gameplay? The ult prevents death. Wait a minute...
You seriously arguing that the ult doesn't fit? They're death. They choose when one lives or dies.

> [{quoted}](name=Thumpin,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=livFTmPP,comment-id=000200020002,timestamp=2016-04-30T00:41:33.764+0000)
>
> You seriously arguing that the ult doesn't fit? They're death. They choose when one lives or dies.

Yes yes, they have dominion over DEATH. Lamb and Wolf do not have a transformation sequence where they transform into Soraka, they are the Grim Reaper,   death incarnate.  Preventing death for a short time makes some sense, but healing afterwards? That is the opposite of death, that is giving life, it doesn't fit. 

And I said from a gameplay perspective you fool, which it most certainty does not, that's a tank ult they're flinging around.
I don't think it works that way. Pretty sure as death they only get to chose when they go.
If you're the ferryman, you get to decide who gets on the boat and who doesn't. They don't HAVE to take someone's life if they don't want to.

So some one's head gets cut off in battle, they can say it isn't their time to go? Because I don't think it works that way. And if you are going to tell me the person was only decapitated becasue Kindred decided it was their time to go. Then you mean to tell me they are ultimately responsible for every decision and every action made. 

The argument is that they can choose who lives and who dies. How? Do they secretly control every person? Or do they use some sort of magic to just make a person survive an other wise fatal blow?

Kindred don't decide who lives and who dies. They just show up to claim the souls of anyone who dies and move them into the afterlife. HOWEVER, they don't have to take someone with them. Have you heard of Charon from Greek mythology? The Greeks made sure that they buried their dead with coins so that they could pay him to carry them to the underworld. Being left without coins meant that you couldn't pass on. Same kinda deal with Kindred - though in their case, they basically just take everyone without thinking about it. 

Also note that Lamb's Respite only lasts for a few seconds. They might not take you immediately, but that doesn't mean they won't take you eventually.

The guy i replied to literally says "they chose when one lives or dies" Explain to me the "they choose when one lives" part. 

How do they actually get a say at all? If one person tries to kill another and they don't want that, what do they do? Reveal themselves to the people and "ult" the person they don't want to die?

The issue with breaking down the abilities of a champion that exists on a more metaphorical level is that not everything works exactly as it does in-game :P

The way I see it, Kindred can choose to NOT take someone when it's their time - in which case, it alters their lifespan. If you've ever seen DeathNote, it's similar to Misa's situation. She was meant to die at the hands of one of her deranged fans, but a shinigami killed the guy before he could kill Misa. So, her life was extended. 

Lamb's Respite is something similar, but if we were to translate it out of the game, it'd be more of you getting a lucky break when you should have died. So, if you about to get hit by a bus and Kindred knew it wasn't your time yet, you'd somehow miraculously get out of the way or only get injured by it. 

It doesn't entirely explain the Kindred's abilities, but I hope that explanation helps somewhat.

When they were developing Kindred, they were thinking of opposites that they felt suited eachother.

Peace and Chaos.
Mercy and Cruelty.
Malice and Innocence.
Coolness and Excitation.
Sophistication and Savagery.
Light and Dark.

In that brainstorm, they put "Life and Death" in that.

The ultimate temporarily lets all within it live, but as we all know, everything goes to hell once the thing ends.
Let's just hope they make a reverse kindred skin with wolf being the archer and lamb being the floating head

Wolf's always there, even if it is a smaller role.

Wolf's main ability, W, allows Kindred to Q quicker, which is her main ability.
Lamb always sends Wolf to deal the killing blow when they E.

He's always there, working in unison with Lamb.

By this logic Lulu and Pix are partners.

But... thats definitely not the case.
Pix also doesn't enable 80% of Lulu's overall damage, unless you're leveling her E first.

Pix helps Lulu's passive, her Q, her W, and her E.
Wolf helps Kindred's W and her E. 

So... Lulu's pet actually helps out more than Lamb's partner. That's not right at all.

I've always found her really pretentious, sort of thing you'd see on a 16 year old's Tumblr with her faux-philosophical quotes and the whole "They're death itself so they're more powerful than everything else ever blah blah" thing. But then that's just me.

I'm curious at how you expect Death personified to act. As well as this iteration being split personalities, as well as hunters. Thematically, I'd think the lines fit quite well infact.

As for power, what would you consider more powerful or final than death? Life is its equal and opposite, but not much else.

There's a trope on TV Tropes called "Holy Sh*t Quotient" or something like that, and I feel that Kindred lore wise goes a bit too far there. Kind of devalues everyone else associated with death like Karthus when we literally have this champion and say "Yeah, she's death itself. Yep". Where can you go with characters from there on? (It's like Arceus in Pokemon. We have all these Pokemon and suddenly we bring in another and say "He made all of them, he's Jesus and he's always been part of the series". You know what I mean? :P)
And if you ask me gameplay wise the Kindred Lamb-Wolf split is about as involving as the Quinn-Valor relationship. Beyond your W and being in the E animation he kind of just floats there....

Have to remember that Kindred as characters are the polar opposite of the sort of character I personally like xD (I've always been more of a fan of the layman sort of character who isn't all wistful and artsy. And that's something we never try to do. If everyone likes something, you can be pretty sure no one loves it. Cool discussion, by the way.
Well then please stop making champs like {{champion:136}} {{champion:432}} {{champion:203}} . Its kinda of lame to keep hearing there gods/death, there more powerful than everyone else just because.

I quite like champions like Aurelion Sol, Bard, and Kindred. They're not gods/death, they're the balance of nature. It's something that the lore needed, because Runeterra used to be vague in terms of what everybody believed in, and it still is vague. There is no determined religion (partially because I think Riot doesn't want to bring religion into the mix) that characters within the game believe in, other than a few characters like Illaoi.

Champions like Bard and Kindred bring in the balance of how everything works - it makes Runeterra seem a lot more mythical, in a sense, and while some people particularly don't like the mythical element and like to go for a more realistic element, Aurelion Sol, Bard, and Kindred bring in a lot of mythical background that may help avid lore-readers understand Runeterra and it's existence a lot better.

In my eyes, champions that bring a mythical or mystical element into the lore is really healthy for the game. As a bonus, Riot doesn't over-glorify these champions and make them seem as powerful as they are in the lore as they are in the game. Kindred, for example, represents life and death - in the lore, they kill, primarily; there is no escaping Kindred's arrow or teeth. Once you have been marked, *"Eternal life calls for you"*, and that's it.
However, in actual gameplay, Kindred's ult, Lamb's Respite, people often refer to it as Lamb is able to decide who lives, and who dies, yet this completely goes against the lore.

You see, Riot doesn't always tie their champions into the lore 100% of the time, which is actually good for champions like Aurelion Sol. While they stay true to the lore, it's not always accurate, and their power is usually limited significantly. That would be rather overpowered if Aurelion Sol could literally make a life-sized star on Summoner's Rift. His Q, however, is similar to that, but it's incredibly scaled down.

They might as well be gods. Aurelion Sol creates stars and universes or some shit. Bard is supposed to be something similar, some sort of all powerful cosmic being. And kindred is supposedly literately death. 

Whats the point in lore when you have these champions that basically win anything, and no one stands a chance against them. They feel like Doctor Manhattan from Watchmen, just really lame uncontested characters.

The problem with Sol is that to have him be an active being, essentially a protagonist, rather than just some mythical being from the lore, it forces dumb plot devices and conveniences that cheapen the writing.

Like that stupid crown the Targonians put on him to enslave him, that literally destroys a star somewhere in the universe if he disobeys them. So like, why did ancient Runeterra have stupid ass technology like this? And why haven't the Targonians long colonized all of Runeterra? Sol raises more dumb questions than he answers.

I think it helps create the fantasy that all are equals in the League, even a simple soldier can defeat the embodiment of death.  It really makes it kind of funny too, how a guy with a shotgun{{champion:104}}  can beat a star creating Dragon-God{{champion:136}}

Kindred resembles life and death, and the story of choosing how you wish to die - by arrow, or teeth - and this entire story is literally embedded into the playstyle of Kindred.

I could go into depth why anyone and everyone that thinks that kindred is the strongest is utterly wrong. but I won't, instead I'll leave this concise.

Kindred doesn't kill people, she doesn't fight people. wolf never attacks people. kindred doesn't do anything. she is just kinda there.

By no means is Kindred the strongest, because Kindred most of the time does not actually participate in existence. It's like God or the Grim Reaper showing up after you died to take you away. You're already dead, they're just there to finalize it.

I can see where you're coming from.
I believe that Riot has stated that Kindred are in fact not the most overpowered entities in Runeterra in terms of lore because they have to use their power sparingly. While they cannot technically die, they will have bouts of dormancy and periodically show up.
The Wiki has stated that Kindred do not like Shadow Isles champions because of how they are between life and death, but if Kindred was so powerful, wouldn't they be able to get rid of the Shadow Isles champions?

I'm not trying to prove you wrong, and I understand why you would think Kindred seems pretentious, but these are just some examples of why Kindred are more than likely not the most overpowered entities in Runeterra. Again, they have to use their power sparingly.

Err.. close, but not quiet. The reason Kindred isn't 'all powerful', is simply because they don't actually do anything. They don't kill people, they're just there to provide closure on the death. They don't really interact with our world much outside of those brief boundary moments between life-and-death.
